text:
Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer from English with 
Jennifer. I've made some embarrassing mistakes

in the past. Have you? Let me tell you about one. 
I was at a wedding. I knew the bride, but not the

groom. I had only seen him from a distance. Well, 
I was walking along a path after the ceremony,

and a man in a tuxedo was about to pass me. I was 
fairly certain it was the groom, so I thought I

should say something. I said, "Congratulations!" 
He said, "Thanks, but I'm not the groom." I was

like, "Oops!" Putting names with faces isn't my 
best skill, at least not outside the classroom.

Sometimes we mistake one person for another. 
It happens. I know I'm not the first to do it.

This is not all that different from mistaking 
one piece of grammar for another. Gerunds and

present participles are both words that end in 
-ing. We form them from verbs: learn - learning,

love - loving, run - running. So, 
not all words that end in -ing

are gerunds, but gerunds behave like nouns. 
Take a look at some parts from my story again

and tell me if the highlighted words are gerunds. 
I've made some embarrassing mistakes in the past.

This isn't a gerund. This is a present 
participle functioning as an adjective.

Some call it a participial adjective. What 
kind of mistakes? Embarrassing mistakes.

-ing adjectives have an active meaning. 
These mistakes cause embarrassment.
I was walking along a path after the ceremony.

This isn't a gerund. This is a present participle, 
and it's part of a verb in the past progressive.

It's an action in progress 
at a past point in time.
Putting names with faces isn't my best skill.

"Putting" is a gerund. I used 
a gerund phrase as the subject

of my sentence. Putting names 
with faces isn't my best skill.

How else can we use gerunds? What else might we 
mistake for a gerund? Do gerunds change forms?
Let's find answers to these questions.

We saw how a gerund or a 
gerund phrase can function

as the subject. Take a look at these 
sentences. How are the gerunds being used?

Do you enjoy meeting new people? 
Are you good at remembering names?

Look back at number one. Enjoy 
what? Enjoy meeting new people.

The gerund phrase is the object of 
the verb. It's the direct object.
And number two. Good at what?

Good at something. The gerund phrase 
is the object of the preposition.
Three. Jennifer's chosen topic,

forgetting people's names, is one 
that other people might relate to.

What was the chosen topic? 
Forgetting people's names.

I'm using the gerund as an appositive. That's a 
noun or a noun phrase that redefines the subject.

We often form appositives when we reduce adjective 
clauses. My father, a medical doctor, is now

retired. What was the full adjective clause? My 
father, who was a medical doctor, is now retired.

So, a noun or noun phrase or a gerund 
or gerund phrase can be an appositive.

Do you remember how I said putting 
names with faces isn't my best skill?

I can flip that around and say, "My best 
skill isn't putting names with faces."

Remember that subject complements 
follow linking verbs. We have the

subject + linking verb (in this case a form 
of BE) and then the subject complement.

It defines the subject. My best skill... 
What is it? Isn't putting names with faces.

To summarize, a gerund or gerund phrase 
can be a subject, object, complement,

or appositive. Try completing these sentences 
for practice. Share your ideas in the comments.

Do you want to know my honest answer to number 
two? In the early morning hours, I enjoy sleeping

in. I also think that a major cause of stress 
is taking on too much and not finding enough

time for ourselves. Would you agree? I just gave 
you an example of a negative gerund. Negative

gerunds are simply "not" + the gerund. Again, 
this gerund or gerund phrase can be a subject,

object, complement, or appositive. How about 
a passive gerund? Do you remember the basic

difference between active voice and passive 
voice? Passive verbs shift the focus to the

person or thing that receives the action. 
The focus shifts away from the performer.

Watching small children is necessary. Watching 
other people is not always appropriate.

For street artists and street performers, 
being watched is completely normal.

Do you like being told what to do? Are 
you ever afraid of being judged harshly?

These are more examples of passive gerunds. 
Passive gerunds use BEING + the past participle.

Go ahead and practice using passive gerunds. 
Write complete answers to my questions.

I can tell you that my son doesn't 
like being told what to do,

especially behind the wheel. He's now 16 going on 
17, and although he's doing a great job as a new

driver, I still get nervous. He doesn't 
have his full license yet, so sometimes

I become a backseat driver. I'm sitting in 
the front passenger seat, but I have a habit

of reminding him to do this and that. I know 
it's annoying, but sometimes I can't help it.

Yes, I'm admitting publicly that my 
backseat driving is annoying my teenage son.

Okay. Look at the sentence and 
tell me where the gerund is.
Driving. "Driving" is the gerund. "Backseat"

is acting as a noun modifier. What 
kind of driving? Backseat driving.
Whose backseat driving? Mine.

We can use possessive forms before a gerund: 
a possessive name or a possessive adjective.

Since gerunds behave like nouns, we can 
use a possessive word before gerund.

Now, something interesting happens in everyday 
English. Sometimes we use just a person's name,
not with an apostrophe -s, just the name

or an object pronoun in front of a 
gerund. And it has the same meaning.

Your telling me what to do at 
every turn makes me nervous.

You telling me what to do at 
every turn makes me nervous.

In fact, the object pronoun sounds more 
natural to my ears in this example.
What do you think neighbors might complain about?

Can you finish my sentences 
with gerunds or gerund phrases?

Here are my ideas. The new neighbors are 
awful. Their partying drives me crazy.

I really want to tell them that their 
dancing on the rooftop has got to stop.

Let's pause for a moment and consider what it 
means to use a possessive adjective before a

gerund. It means we can use other adjectives 
-- other modifiers -- before gerunds.
The neighbor's loud partying is a problem.

Constant sneezing is typical of spring 
allergies. Slow dancing is very romantic.

The hard part is done. The rest of 
the project should be smooth sailing.

We've now seen a simple gerund, 
a simple gerund that's negative,

a passive gerund, and a 
so-called possessive gerund.

Having covered simple, passive, and 
possessive forms should fill you with

more confidence. At least, I hope so. You're 
ready to look at two final forms: past forms.
Look at my subject.

I used a very long subject with a perfect gerund. 
A perfect gerund is a past form of a gerund.
We use HAVING + a past participle.

For regular verbs, that's the -ed form. For 
irregular verbs. it's the third form of the verb.

We don't often need this form, but 
it's useful when we need to clarify

that one action happened at an earlier past 
point in time. I said, "Having covered simple,

passive, and possessive forms should fill 
you with more confidence." In other words,

we covered other forms of gerunds earlier, 
so now you should have more confidence.
Guess what? A perfect gerund can also be passive.

My backseat driving is bothersome. I guess I 
appreciate having been told. I'll do it less.

Besides, he really is getting 
better, so he needs less direction.

The passive form of a perfect or past 
gerund is HAVING BEEN + the past participle:
having been told.

Again, he told me earlier, so now I know 
what not to do. Can you finish these ideas?

Let me note one pattern. If the time sequence is 
clear, we can use the simple gerund. For example,

my country takes pride in 
having put a man on the moon.

I want to use the perfect gerund here because it 
makes a clear reference to the past. But look at

this example. Having been taught to respect others 
at a young age made me the person I am today.

I feel the time sequence is clear because we have 
two time markers: "at a young age" and "today."

So personally, I think it's fine to say, 
"Being taught to respect others at a young age
made me the person I am today."

And truthfully, we don't use perfect gerunds 
all that much in everyday spoken English.

Do you remember how I talked about mistaken 
identity at the beginning of the lesson?

Well, here's a related challenge. Can 
you identify which sentence has a gerund?

A. The parents appreciated having 
been warned about the strong currents,

so they kept their children in 
the shallow water at the beach.

And B. Having been warned 
about the strong currents,

the parents kept their children 
in the shallow water at the beach.
Let's consider these examples carefully.

Not all sources and not all teachers will agree 
with me, but I feel that sentence A has a gerund.

Sentence A has a passive gerund in a past 
form functioning as the object of the verb:

appreciated. Appreciated what? In my 
mind, sentence B has a participial phrase,

an adverbial phrase, and it explains a reason. 
Why? I see a reduced adverb clause in sentence B.

Because the parents had been 
warned about the strong currents,

they kept their children in 
the shallow water at the beach.

There is debate about gerunds and participles. For 
example, following time words like AFTER, BEFORE,

and WHILE, we can have -ing forms. Some 
simply call those words -ing forms.

However, others like to label them as either 
gerunds or participles. I see arguments for both.

If you consider AFTER and BEFORE prepositions, 
then you can see gerunds in these examples:

After swimming, we had lunch. 
Before heading to the beach,

we put on sunblock. Preposition + object. However, 
if you consider AFTER and BEFORE as conjunctions,

subordinating conjunctions left over 
from reduced adverb clauses of time,

then you likely see them as participles. 
The full adverb clauses of time are:

After we swam, we had lunch. Before we 
headed to the beach, we put on sunblock.

Remember that WHILE also helps us form adverb 
clauses of time that reduce to adverb phrases,

so why isn't WHILE listed as a preposition 
in the dictionary? It's only a conjunction.

Why would two conjunctions transform into 
prepositions and a third wouldn't? While

I was relaxing on the beach, I got a nice tan. 
While relaxing on the beach, I got a nice tan.

I usually see all these examples with 
AFTER, BEFORE, and WHILE + -ing forms
as adverb phrases reduced from adverb clauses.

But to be honest, I'd rather find a compromise 
than argue. Maybe we can just call them -ing

forms in those phrases. We can also talk 
about -ing forms in these kinds of examples.

Do you have trouble making small talk? Are you 
comfortable talking to people you just met?

I definitely see those phrases as complements. 
The first is an object complement.

The second is an adjective complement. I'd rather 
not argue whether they're gerunds or participles,

so I'm willing to call them -ing 
forms. That's probably less confusing.

If you'd like to learn more about reducing adverb 
clauses, you can watch my four-part lesson on this

topic. I'll put the link in the video description. 
Here's a final quiz. Let's test what you learned.
One. Which word is a gerund?
Two. Which gerund is passive?
Three. Which gerund is a past form?
Four. Can you fix the mistake?
Five. Can you fix the mistake?

We'll end here. I hope that looking at lots of 
examples was useful. Practicing grammar together

makes it easier to learn, and I certainly 
hope that you feel more confident using

gerunds now. Please like and share the video. As 
always, thanks for watching and happy studies!

Follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and 
Instagram. Why not join me on Patreon?
And don't forget to subscribe on YouTube.
